text.p: Electrochemical Industries said on Monday it signed an agreement with representatives of employees at its Acre Plant to end a labor dispute and to extend its labor agreement for an additional two years.
The Israeli company said it estimated the deal would save it about $10 million to $12 million in annual fixed costs.

Under the agreement, the company said payroll costs at its Acre Plant will be reduced over the year without hurting the plant's output. Inefficient installations would be closed, and manpower and payroll costs would be reduced, it said.
Electrochemical also said it was now possible to implement its business program.
During this period the company said it would have one-time retirement expenses which would be lower than half of the expected annual saving.
In addition, Electrochemical said its collective labor agreement was extended for another two years with amendments to prevent an unreasonable increase in future payroll costs.
